channel.title: Finding RS window in Java
channel.description:
You know the way scar works with it's autos, where it finds the RS game window on the screen?
Is there an easy way to do this in Java, and if so, what functions, etc. would be used?
Edit: I think one method of doing it would be to just find the top right of the window on the screen by looking for it's colors, and then knowing where the rest is from there....

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Who said he had to use native code? Just because it’s the immediately apparent solution to the problem, dosen’t mean there’s not an equally simple one hiding somewhere.

Read full topic

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @RLN RLN
item.description:
@RLN wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:9, topic:91311”][quote author=semaphore link=topic=133092.msg1293930#msg1293930 date=1178816694]

The issue with that is, you then lose portability completely.

Portability is grossly overrated. This is one of the common myths concerning java code: ‘It must be portable’. The truth is, once you decide on the platform to run something, you don’t change it barring exceptional circumstances.
[/quote]

Sure, if you’re sitting in an office writing code for systems with predetermined operating systems.

If you are releasing something on the internet though, why not make it portable? Especially when using a language where it is incredibly easy to do so.[/quote]Not incredibly easy to do when you need to use native code

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman

[quote=“semaphore, post:8, topic:91311”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=133092.msg1286267#msg1286267 date=1178667563]
The issue with that is, you then lose portability completely.
[/quote]

Portability is grossly overrated. This is one of the common myths concerning java code: ‘It must be portable’. The truth is, once you decide on the platform to run something, you don’t change it barring exceptional circumstances.[/quote]

Sure, if you’re sitting in an office writing code for systems with predetermined operating systems.

If you are releasing something on the internet though, why not make it portable? Especially when using a language where it is incredibly easy to do so.

Read full topic

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Mopman:

The issue with that is, you then lose portability completely.

Portability is grossly overrated. This is one of the common myths concerning java code: ‘It must be portable’. The truth is, once you decide on the platform to run something, you don’t change it barring exceptional circumstances.

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @Repentless Repentless
item.description:
@Repentless wrote:

[quote=“rs2crash, post:1, topic:91380”]http://www.gimlisys.com/x10gimli/doc/X10Gimli/Native/WindowsAPI.html
or
http://johannburkard.de/software/nativecall/

and found a example using nativecall library

[code]
public static Integer FindWindowEx(Integer parentHandle, Integer childAfter, String lclassName, String windowTitle) {
int tempVal;

	IntCall cT = new IntCall("user32", "FindWindowExA");
	tempVal = cT.executeCall(new Object[] {parentHandle, childAfter, lclassName, windowTitle});
	cT.destroy();
	
	return new Integer(tempVal);
}

[/code][/quote]

Thanks That will be useful in the future. Well, at least in Windows versions of whatever I make. But since that is Windows only, exactly what Mopman said. Again, how would you find the location of an image (as string) on the screen?

Read full topic

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

The issue with that is, you then lose portability completely.

Read full topic

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @Repentless Repentless
item.description:
@Repentless wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:2, topic:91311”]That’s a terrible way of doing it.

Thanks to the awesomeness of Java, you can create a loader, make your own frame around the client, and not have to guess where the client is.[/quote]

Yes, I see what you’re saying, but I already knew that

Well, forget about guessing where the RuneScape client is. Let’s just leave that out for now. What I’m trying to do is make a java program that is not a reverse-engineered rs client. So, I still need to be able to find colors/images on the screen. How do you find specific colors and images on the screen, the way scar works? I googled, but to no avail.

Read full topic

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Er… the Runescape window dosen’t have a titlebar or any other kind of component that is dependant on “the standard XP window color”.

Read full topic

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @PKERZ PKERZ
item.description:
@PKERZ wrote:

If you did that, wouldn’t you only be able to use this on java programs? I think there could be other ways of getting the coordinates in which you should click with your robot component. If you use the robot with a GraphicsDevice, that would be possible (as to what i know).

And the thing you were talking about Repentless, would first of all take too long to initialize. And if you got another color than blue (or the standard XP window color) it wouldn’t really work, because it would never really find the correct place. At last, it wouldn’t either know where the end of the window would be.

Read full topic

item.title: Finding RS window in Java
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

That’s a terrible way of doing it.

Thanks to the awesomeness of Java, you can create a loader, make your own frame around the client, and not have to guess where the client is.

Read full topic
